articles.title: 9,000 metres under the sea: this researcher found the deepest animal ecosystems on Earth
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 08 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03843-6Mengran Du is part of Nature‚Äôs 10, a list of people who shaped science in 2025.
articles.content:
Looking out of the Fendouzhe submersible, more than nine kilometres below the ocean surface, Mengran Du knew she was seeing something totally new to science. The vessel‚Äôs lights illuminated a thriving ecosystem in which ghostly bristleworms swim among fields of blood-red tubeworms.

Du and her colleagues were exploring the hadal zone ‚Äî the lowermost layer of the ocean, found beyond depths of six kilometres. Here, at the bottom of the Kuril‚ÄìKamchatka Trench northeast of Japan, Du and her team discovered the deepest-known ecosystem with animals on the planet during dives in 2024, which they described this year (X. Peng et al. Nature 645, 679‚Äì685; 2025). ‚ÄúAs a diving scientist, I always have the curiosity to know the unknowns about hadal trenches,‚Äù says Du, a geoscientist at the Chinese Academy of Sciences‚Äô Institute of Deep-sea Science and Engineering in Sanya, China. ‚ÄúThe best way to know the unknown is to go there and feel it with your heart and experience, and look at the bottom with your bare eyes.‚Äù

The ecosystem discovered by the Fendouzhe crew relies on an unusual source of energy. Unlike most life at the surface, which depends on sunlight, this hadal-zone ecosystem derives energy from methane, hydrogen sulfide and other compounds dissolved in fluids that seep up from the ocean floor. Chemosynthetic microbes use these energy-rich molecules to convert inorganic carbon into carbohydrates that then support the rest of the ecosystem. Du was the first to observe several species of gastropods, tubeworms, clams and other creatures in these ‚Äòcold seeps‚Äô, several of which are likely to be new to science, she says.

‚ÄúMengran has made a great contribution to these expeditions,‚Äù says Xiaotong Peng, deputy director of the Institute of Deep-sea Science and Engineering, who was also in the submersible. He says Du‚Äôs experience in coastal research allowed her to identify species found in chemosynthetic communities while they were still on the sea floor, an important skill for determining the significance of findings. ‚ÄúShe has a great passion for deep-sea science, and that is one of the reasons why we can find such amazing phenomena at the sea floor,‚Äù he adds.

The discovery prompted the team to change its plans during the 2024 expedition, says Peng. The researchers took the Fendouzhe submersible to search for chemosynthetic ecosystems at more sites, including in the nearby Aleutian Trench.

Du, who was the chief scientific officer for the expedition, and her colleagues completed 24 dives in the submersible, which last an average of around 6 hours. Built out of titanium to withstand crushing pressures of 98 megapascals ‚Äî about 1,000 times the air pressure at sea level ‚Äî the submersible has an area for the crew that is just 1.8 metres and holds three people.

This year, Du, Peng and their colleagues conducted expeditions to another trench in the southern Pacific Ocean, where they found ecosystems that are similar to those they found in the northern part of the ocean last year. This offers strong evidence that there is a global corridor of chemosynthetic ecosystems across Earth‚Äôs oceans, say the researchers.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery of the deepest-known animal ecosystems on Earth, revealing new species and a global corridor of chemosynthetic ecosystems. This has broad implications for understanding deep-sea biodiversity and Earth's ecosystems, representing a meaningful advancement in environmental science.

articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** ‚Äì Scientists have long explored the deep ocean, but the lowest layer, called the hadal zone, lies beyond 6,000 meters deep and is mostly unknown. This zone is found in deep ocean trenches like the Kuril-Kamchatka Trench northeast of Japan.

**What happened** ‚Äì In 2024, a team led by researcher Mengran Du dived nearly 9,000 meters deep in a submersible named Fendouzhe. They discovered the deepest-known ecosystem with animals on Earth. This ecosystem includes strange creatures like ghostly bristleworms and bright red tubeworms living around cold seeps, where chemical-rich fluids come out of the ocean floor.

**Impact** ‚Äì Unlike most life depending on sunlight, this deep ecosystem uses energy from chemicals like methane and hydrogen sulfide. This discovery revealed new species and showed that similar ecosystems exist in other ocean trenches, suggesting a global network of deep-sea life forms. It changes how we understand life in extreme environments and Earth's biodiversity.

**What's next step** ‚Äì The team plans to explore more trenches to learn how widespread these ecosystems are. They will continue using the Fendouzhe submersible to study these habitats and identify new species, helping us understand deep-ocean ecosystems better.

**One-sentence takeaway** ‚Äì For the first time, scientists have found and described the deepest animal ecosystems on Earth, thriving nearly 9,000 meters underwater by using chemical energy instead of sunlight.

articles.title: Sustainability In Your Ear: Building The Circular Economy With Glacier CEO Rebecca Hu-Thrams
articles.summary:
Subscribe to receive transcripts by email. Read along with this episode. The raw material for...
The post Sustainability In Your Ear: Building The Circular Economy With Glacier CEO Rebecca Hu-Thrams appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Subscribe to receive transcripts by email. Read along with this episode.

The raw material for a $2 trillion circular economy is already flowing through recycling facilities. But how do we capture and use it? Rebecca Hu-Thrams, co-founder and CEO of Glacier, is deploying AI-powered robotic sorters at material recovery facilities (MRFs) across the country, processing recycling for one in 10 Americans. Her robots use computer vision trained on more than 3 billion images of waste to identify and sort over 70 different materials‚Äîpicking 45 items per minute, 24/7, in conditions that would exhaust or injure human workers. As much as 80% of what Americans put in blue bins never gets recycled. The culprit is outdated technology at MRFs, the vast sorting operations struggling with a labor crisis so severe that facilities often refill the same sorting job five times a year. The work is dangerous, with injury rates twice that of construction. Rebecca, a first-generation American who grew up washing margarine tubs for reuse, saw an opportunity to apply cutting-edge technology to what she calls ‚Äúthe most demented form of manufacturing on the planet.‚Äù The results are tangible. At oneDetroit MRF, an AI camera on a residue line revealed the facility was losing massive amounts of PET bottles to landfill, material they suspected was slipping through but had never quantified. By adding a single sorter based on that data, they achieved a two-thirds drop in PET sent to landfill and earned $138,000 in additional annual revenue.

But Glacier‚Äôs robots do more than sort. They create an intelligence layer for the circular economy, generating data about what‚Äôs actually in the waste stream‚Äîdown to specific brands and packaging designs. Amazon, which has invested in Glacier through its Climate Pledge fund, is using this data to understand what design features make packaging easier or harder for AI to detect, moving from ‚Äútechnically recyclable‚Äù to ‚Äúprovably recyclable.‚Äù With extended producer responsibility (EPR) laws spreading across the U.S., this kind of brand-level accountability will become table stakes. Rebecca notes that EPR has improved recycling rates by over 40 percentage points in parts of Europe. Glacier‚Äôs vision is to transform recycling from a reactive cost center into advanced manufacturing, built on three pillars: a reliable data layer, consistent automation, and higher-quality feedstock. ‚ÄúMRF managers show up to work, turn on the lights, and hold their breath and wait to see what new, crazy things come down their conveyor lines,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhat I hope is true for recycling in the coming years is that producers are making things designed to be really easy to recycle.‚Äù

We‚Äôre still in the early steps of a long recycling evolution, but the gap between where we are and a truly circular economy may close faster than the past 60 years of recycling‚Äôs progress would suggest. You can learn more about Glacier at endwaste.io.

articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** ‚Äì Recycling in the United States faces big challenges. Many materials put in blue recycling bins never get recycled because sorting centers use old technology and struggle to find enough workers. The work is hard and can be dangerous.

**What happened** ‚Äì Rebecca Hu-Thrams, CEO of Glacier, has introduced robots powered by artificial intelligence (AI) to help sort recycling at centers across the country. These robots use computer vision trained on billions of images to identify and sort over 70 types of materials quickly and safely. One robot can pick 45 items every minute, working nonstop.

**Impact** ‚Äì Glacier‚Äôs robots have helped recycling centers reduce waste sent to landfills and increase income. For example, one facility in Detroit cut the amount of plastic bottles thrown away by two-thirds and earned an extra $138,000 a year. The robots also collect detailed data about the waste, helping companies like Amazon design packaging that is easier to recycle.

**What's next step** ‚Äì As new laws require companies to take more responsibility for their packaging, this technology will be important for tracking and improving recycling. Glacier hopes to make recycling more automated and reliable so that producers create products designed to be recycled easily.

**One-sentence takeaway** ‚Äì AI-powered robots are making recycling safer, smarter, and more effective, helping reduce waste and improve how materials are reused across the U.S.

articles.title: Sustainable Holidays: Gifts for the Kids
articles.summary:
This holiday season, we can set a sustainable example for the little ones in our...
The post Sustainable Holidays: Gifts for the Kids appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
This holiday season, we can set a sustainable example for the little ones in our lives with gifts that consider our impact on the planet. The good news: eco-conscious toy options have expanded dramatically. According to a 2024 Toy Association survey, 45% of parents under 40 now consider a toy‚Äôs sustainability credentials before purchasing.

It‚Äôs the most consumption-oriented time of the year. In addition to choosing fun, sustainable gifts, set an Earth-conscious example by using waste-free and low-waste gift-wrapping ideas, shopping locally, and planning meals to avoid piles of leftover food after family dinners, and by helping the kiddos understand how and where to recycle cards and gift wrap. You‚Äôll help your descendants set lifelong habits with the efforts you make today.

Join us in making this holiday season green, merry, and bright for our kids and planet.

Explore the growing number of sustainably made, durable, easily recyclable, and entertaining gift ideas that can delight children and demonstrate your family‚Äôs commitment to our environment. We‚Äôve updated our list with new options from companies that use sustainably sourced materials, employ responsible manufacturing practices, and offer durable designs built to last.

This article contains affiliate links. If you purchase an item through one of these links, we receive a small commission that helps fund our Recycling Directory.

Toys

Green Toys Recycling Truck teaches sustainability through play.

What better way to introduce environmental concepts than a recycling truck made from recycled materials? This truck features three sorting chutes for bottles, cans, and paper, to help kids learn recycling basics while playing. Made in the USA from 100% recycled plastic milk jugs, it contains no BPA, phthalates, or PVC and is dishwasher safe. Even the packaging uses recycled materials and soy-based inks. Green Toys has led the way in eco-friendly toy manufacturing since its founding, proving sustainable playthings can be as fun as conventional options.

Tegu Magnetic Wooden Blocks combine creativity with social impact.

These ingeniously designed wooden blocks contain safely embedded magnets to let kids build gravity-defying structures. Made from sustainably sourced Honduran hardwoods with non-toxic, water-based lacquer finishes, Tegu blocks are designed to last generations. Beyond materials, Tegu‚Äôs mission includes creating jobs and positive social impact in Honduras, one of the Western Hemisphere‚Äôs poorest countries. Available in sets from pocket-sized 8-piece pouches to comprehensive 130-piece classroom sets.

PlanToys Wooden Ocean Animal Set brings nature to imaginative play.

This 4-piece Montessori-inspired playset includes a dolphin, an orca, a shark, and a second whale, all crafted from rubberwood trees that no longer produce latex. PlanToys operates a solar-powered factory in Thailand and uses organic pigments, water-based dyes, and formaldehyde-free glue. The company pioneered the use of reclaimed rubber plantation wood for toys over 40 years ago and aims to achieve carbon neutrality, which will set them apart as a leader in sustainable toy manufacturing.

GUND Sustainably Soft Plush Collection offers huggable friends made from recycled materials.

America‚Äôs oldest teddy bear maker now offers a line of plush toys crafted entirely from recycled materials‚Äîincluding the fabric, stuffing, thread, and even the packaging. The collection includes teddy bears, bunnies, puppies, baby dolls, and popular characters like Bluey and Bingo. GUND‚Äôs sustainable line maintains the same premium softness the brand has been known for since 1898, proving eco-friendly can also be irresistibly cuddly. Gund also offers a remarkable replacement program, Forever Friends, that makes your gift a lifelong companion.

Honeysticks beeswax crayons for many hours of fun.

Made from beeswax and food-grade pigments, Honeysticks‚Äô oversized crayons are a sweet-smelling way for kids to start their relationship with arts and crafts. The jumbo-size crayons are easy to hold and designed to help kids develop their pencil grip. They are made with naturally sourced honey wax and sustainably sourced U.S. soy wax. And Honeysticks‚Äô packaging is made from recycled, recyclable materials.

Wild Planet Ecokins are fun, huggable stuffies for a lifetime of ecological awareness.

Wild Planet offers a menagerie of EcoKins sustainable plush toys, including elephants, alligators, bears, sharks, penguins, and more. You‚Äôll be doing the planet a favor by choosing these stuffed animals made entirely from recycled materials. About 16 PET bottles are recycled to make the large animals‚Äô fabric and stuffing, while the hang tags are produced from post-consumer paper and attached with a cotton, not plastic, string.

Home and School Gear

Green Toys Build-a-Bouquet blooms year-round from recycled milk jugs.

This colorful 44-piece set lets kids create endless floral arrangements with stackable lilies, petunias, and daisies. Made in the USA from 100% recycled plastic milk jugs, it develops fine motor skills while saving energy and reducing greenhouse gas emissions compared to virgin plastic production. The vibrant flowers stack interchangeably on stems for limitless creativity in all seasons.

Reusable Magnetic Water Balloons eliminate single-use summer waste.

Traditional water balloons create significant litter and pose wildlife hazards. Smirodi‚Äôs silicone alternatives can be reused over 1,000 times. And filling them is easy: submerge them in water to fill, and the magnetic seal snaps closed. When the fun is done, no balloon fragments litter your yard. Several brands offer sets of 6-12 balloons with mesh storage bags, making them an economical and eco-responsible choice for summer parties.

Deluxebase Eco 3D Wooden Puzzles build fine motor skills and wildlife awareness.

These laser-cut animal puzzles are crafted from sustainably sourced natural wood, with smooth edges that make them safe for young builders. Choose from more than 30 creatures that kids can build to develop hand-eye coordination, spatial awareness, and patience. Unlike single-use craft kits, these puzzles can be assembled and disassembled repeatedly for lasting play value. Deluxebase brings over 25 years of toy design experience to this collection, and the wildlife themes offer natural opportunities to discuss animal habitats and conservation. At party-favor-friendly prices, they make excellent alternatives to plastic goodie bag fillers.

Customize the lunchtime experience with Lunchbots Build-a-Bento.

It may be time for a practical holiday gift. If you want to give a gift that reminds your kids of the holidays every day, the Lunchbots Build-a-Bento lunch box is a colorful and durable choice. Your kids can customize the interior, allowing them to choose the number of spaces they want. Made of BPA-free food-grade silicone, this bento is dishwasher and microwave-safe, ready for the toughest lunchroom use. When it‚Äôs time to retire this bento box, you may not have a local silicone recycling option, but the company also offers stainless steel options.

Books

Kids always need to have a book close at hand. It keeps them thinking and busy and helps build their ability to focus. Here are a few of our favorite books recognized for their environmental messages.

Help your kids become an Eyewitness Climate Change.

Give your kiddos a solid foundation for understanding the complicated issue of climate change. As Earth911 contributor Sarah Lozanova wrote, ‚ÄúThis book presents a solid overview of the climate, both past and present, and the impacts of climate change. The book concludes with positive actions on how to cut carbon emissions through green transportation, energy efficiency, nuclear power, and renewable energy.‚Äù

How to Change Everything: The Young Human‚Äôs Guide to Protecting the Planet and Each Other empowers the next generation.

Award-winning journalist Naomi Klein adapted her two decades of climate reporting to create this comprehensive environmental guide for young readers. The book provides a thorough look at how we got here, where climate science stands today, and‚Äîmost importantly‚Äîwhat young people can do about it. Full of empowering stories of youth climate leaders from around the world, it connects climate action to broader social justice movements. Kirkus Reviews gave it a starred review, calling it ‚Äúa uniquely inclusive perspective that will inspire conviction, passion, and action. If you can get only one climate change book for youth, let it be this one.‚Äù Ideal for ages 10 and up.

Get activated with To Change a Planet.

Selected as the 2023 Green Earth Book Awards-winning picture book, this beautiful, color-saturated story by Christina Soontornvat and illustrated by Rahele Jomeour Bellfollows follows diverse characters through their daily lives until their stories converge at a climate march in Washington, D.C. The well-researched environmental messages are presented in calm, simple language that even the youngest children can understand.

Consider experience gifts instead of physical items.

Museum memberships, nature center passes, music lessons, or a camping trip create lasting memories without adding to the toy pile. Many families find that the gift of experience can become cherished traditions.

DIY toys reduce packaging waste to zero.

A jumbo cardboard box can become hours of entertainment as a playhouse or rocket ship. Pinterest offers countless ideas for homemade toys, and for those with woodworking skills, plans for wooden toys are readily available online.

articles.title: Illinois families are going electric ‚Äî for free
articles.content:
Jean Gay-Robinson said she ‚Äã‚Äúcried tears of joy‚Äù when utility ComEd switched all the polluting gas-fired equipment in her Chicago home to modern electric versions, at no cost to her. As a retiree on a fixed income, she is relieved that she‚Äôll likely never have to buy another appliance, her energy bills are lower, and her home feels safer. ‚Äã‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have to worry about gas blowing up or carbon monoxide, that kind of nonsense,‚Äù she said.

Gay-Robinson is among the hundreds of people who have benefited from a provision of Illinois‚Äô 2021 clean energy law that allows electric utilities to meet energy-conservation mandates in part by outfitting low-income households with electric appliances that reduce their bills ‚Äî even though such overhauls actually increase, rather than decrease, electricity use.

Such policies are rare nationwide, but the approach could be a tool to help keep building decarbonization rolling as the Trump administration kills federal incentives for home electrification.

Modern electrical appliances ‚Äî like induction stoves, electric dryers, and heat pumps that warm and cool spaces ‚Äî are generally much more energy-efficient than their fossil-fueled counterparts. That means electrifying appliances cuts the amount of fossil fuels burned, even in places where gas and coal plants feed the power grid, said Nick Montoni, senior program director of policy and markets at the North Carolina Clean Energy Technology Center at North Carolina State University. As more renewable energy comes online, the emissions linked to electrical appliances decrease even further.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Plus, families breathe significantly cleaner indoor air when they change to an electric cooktop, due to the slew of health-harming pollutants emitted by gas stoves.

But replacing appliances is not cheap, and under the Trump administration‚Äôs budget law, federal tax credits to help households afford electric heat pumps and water heaters expire in December ‚Äî seven years earlier than they were previously supposed to. Meanwhile, the future is uncertain for the federally funded Home Electrification and Appliance Rebates (HEAR) program, an Inflation Reduction Act initiative that is administered by states and provides incentives for electric appliances. While some states have already launched their HEAR programs, the Trump administration put the remaining funds on ice earlier this year, and Illinois has not yet received its allotment.

Amid this federal upheaval, state policies that incentivize utilities to pick up the tab for electrification can be especially impactful.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs expensive to electrify because it requires up-front cost,‚Äù said Montoni, who formerly served as deputy chief of staff at the Department of Energy‚Äôs Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy. ‚Äã‚ÄúYou have to be able to afford a heat pump, an induction stove, an electric water heater ‚Äî those aren‚Äôt inexpensive. That‚Äôs why there are rebates and incentives.‚Äù

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Illinois utilities commit to electrification

Illinois law requires ComEd to cut electricity consumption each year by an amount equivalent to 2 percent of the utility‚Äôs annual sales in the early 2020s. The state‚Äôs other big electric utility, Ameren, faces similar rules in 2029 under a law passed this fall, though in the past it had lower savings mandates.

The 2021 Climate and Equitable Jobs Act specifies that a portion of mandated energy savings ‚Äî 5 percent since 2022, 10 percent starting next year, and 15 percent after 2029 ‚Äî can come from electrification. The law also created a formula to convert the amount of energy used by a gas-powered appliance to electricity in kilowatt-hours, allowing an estimate of how much energy is saved by switching from gas to electric.

‚ÄúSo if a home gets partially or fully electrified through an electric energy-efficiency program, the utility claims the savings by calculating the difference between the gas therms in kilowatt-hour equivalents and the kilowatt[-hours] added via the electric measures,‚Äù explained Kari Ross, Midwest energy affordability advocate for the Natural Resources Defense Council.

Montoni called the policy ‚Äã‚Äúa pretty interesting mechanism ‚Äî not unique, but very rare, from what I‚Äôve seen.‚Äù

Michigan does have a similar policy, since a 2023 law allows electric and gas utilities to claim electrification as part of their mandatory energy-waste reduction. That legislation also includes a formula for determining the energy-efficiency gains from going electric.

Montoni said allowing electric utilities to count electrification toward their efficiency mandates is an important way to incentivize the shift off fossil fuels, especially in the more than a dozen states where different utilities provide electric and gas service.

When a utility provides both gas and electricity, electrification will typically show overall energy savings, Montoni explained. But when a utility provides only electricity, a formula similar to Illinois‚Äô is needed for the utility to show that it is saving energy, even though a given customer‚Äôs electricity use actually increases after electrification.

In northern Illinois, ComEd is the primary electric utility, operating alongside two major gas utilities.

Through its whole-home energy-efficient electrification program, ComEd pays all up-front costs for electric appliances and heat pumps for households earning at or below 80 percent of the area median income. That initiative has electrified over 700 low-income households since it launched in 2022. The utility also offers rebates for customers of any income for purchasing electric appliances, including geothermal heat pumps.

ComEd‚Äôs energy-efficiency plan approved by state regulators says that a quarter of energy savings from electrification must be for low-income households, and the utility can undertake electrification only if it will save a customer money on their energy bills. Michigan‚Äôs law includes a similar provision.

‚ÄúWe carefully model each home to make sure proposed upgrades result in energy savings,‚Äù said Philip Roy, ComEd‚Äôs director of clean energy solutions. ‚Äã‚ÄúNationally, I‚Äôm pretty sure this is one of the more ambitious approaches to electrification, especially for income-eligible customers.‚Äù

Gay-Robinson said she has saved some money on her bills since her home‚Äôs overhaul last summer, and more importantly, she has reliable appliances to get through Chicago‚Äôs extreme weather.

She recommended the ComEd overhaul to a friend, who was suffering through hot summers in poor health and without air-conditioning. Gay-Robinson thinks the electric heating-cooling system her friend got at no cost may have saved her life.

Gay-Robinson said she still prefers cooking with gas, but she‚Äôs grateful ComEd provided new cookware along with her electric induction stove. ‚Äã‚ÄúI thought it would be hard to even work the doggone stove. It looks like something out of the future,‚Äù she said. ‚Äã‚ÄúBut it wasn‚Äôt as hard as I thought.‚Äù

More retrofits like Gay-Robinson‚Äôs are on the way. In an agreement with stakeholder groups and regulators, ComEd has committed to spend a total of $162.3 million over the next four years on electrification and weatherization, which reduces the amount of power needed to heat and cool spaces.

In central and southern Illinois, Ameren provides both gas and electric service.

Ameren has not undertaken ambitious electrification programs like ComEd, and it had lower energy-efficiency mandates until the clean energy law passed in October brought its targets into parity with ComEd‚Äôs. But Ameren will spend $5 million through 2029 helping customers switch from propane-fired heat, which is common in rural areas, to electric heat pumps.

Changing times

Home-electrification retrofits that lower energy bills may be harder to come by in Illinois and beyond in the future, as electricity prices spike due to the record-high cost of securing enough power-generating capacity for the PJM Interconnection regional grid, which spans 13 states.

Since ComEd is only allowed to offer customers new electrical appliances that will reduce their bills, high electricity prices mean some exchanges that worked in the past will no longer qualify; keeping a gas appliance may be cheaper.

‚ÄúWe are in a moment where further iteration is needed‚Äù on electrification policies, said Roy, also citing the impacts of President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs on appliance costs and the looming expiration of federal tax credits for energy-efficient equipment.

Roy noted that with rooftop solar and batteries, a household can tap clean, free electricity to power their appliances. Illinois has robust incentives for low-income households to obtain solar, potentially at no up-front cost.

‚ÄúWe see a lot of momentum with these programs,‚Äù said Roy. ‚Äã‚ÄúWe think [electrification] will play a key role in not just energy-efficiency goals but broader energy policy. Combining all those elements ‚Äî traditional energy efficiency, electrification, rooftop solar, battery storage ‚Äî we have a lot of the tools, we just have to fine-tune the policy structures and incentives so we can accelerate the transition.‚Äù
